rCKINx-y6.memHandModelNotes: This species does not occur in closed canopy environments (Means 2004), use forest interior mask as an AVOID mask. Since species uses edges of Floodplains, bottomlands, ponds, streams & swamps (Mount 1975, Wilson 1995, Palmer & Braswell 1995). I selected all these types as AMUs and used a 250m from buffer since species is more mobile. Could not locate home range or daily movement information for this species so used body size/mobility index and applied a 250m buffer for both avoid and AMU. Amy Silvano 22Aug05

habitat_description:
From NatureServe
Estuarine Habitat(s): Herbaceous wetland
Palustrine Habitat(s): FORESTED WETLAND, HERBACEOUS WETLAND, Riparian, SCRUB-SHRUB WETLAND
Terrestrial Habitat(s): Bare rock/talus/scree, Cropland/hedgerow, Desert, Grassland/herbaceous, Old field, Sand/dune, Savanna, Shrubland/chaparral, Woodland - Conifer, Woodland - Hardwood, Woodland - Mixed

Habitat Comments: Habitats vary geographically and include open coniferous forest, woodland, swamps, coastal marshes, river bottoms, farmland, prairie, chaparral, and desert. 

From SWReGAP
Stebbins (2003) and Degenhardt et al. (1996) state this species frequents a variety of habitats- coniferous forests, woodland, swampland, coastal marshes, river bottoms, farmland, prairie, chaparral, and desert.  This species is found near rock outcrops and clumps of vegetation, and under rotting logs, old lumber, and rocks (Stebbins 2003).  Species is found in low, hilly semi-desert shrubland, irrigated fields, cottonwood-Russian olive groves, and plains grasslands (Hammerson).  In New Mexico, preferred habitat is riparian (majority of collections have been along principal river systems) or grassland, but some are found in pinon-juniper, and low elevation desert areas (Degenhardt et al. 1996).  This species uses all kinds of surface cover, but in desert areas it uses rock outcrops or rodent burrows (as long as it is sufficient depth to escape hot dry conditions); it often uses old houses, barns, foundations, wells, and cisterns for retreats (Degenhardt et al. 1996).  In New Mexico can be found from 900-1800m (Degenhardt et al. 1996). Stebbins (2003) states this snake can be found from sea level to 2130m.
